Another issue with stuff like boycotting a Pokémon game is that even all those that said they would boycott the game were only a small fraction of the whole potential playerbase.
The rest were mostly casual players that either didn't even know about the dexit stuff or just didn't care enough about it.
So even if everyone that said they would boycott the game actually did so, it likely wouldn't have mattered much at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem with the "gamer boycott" is that most of the time, the term is used by some person who wishes to insist that his choice not to buy a game needs to have some greater worldwide significance.


I don't buy Squeenix games, because I hate Squeenix's practices. I don't buy goldfish crackers anymore, either, precisely because of a decision they made years ago to increase the package size. While both of these decisions might technically fit the definition of "boycott", I don't call it such, because I don't really care to broadcast every decision I make...
...
...except these decisions, apparently. Just shut up.

snippet.textDisplay:
There are many, many games I haven't bought or played, and many films and shows I haven't seen or given money to out of principal of bad business practices or just bad product.

I don't really trust, Jim, that what examples were shown were representative of boycotts in general when the examples were of two of the most 'basic' and, frankly, infantile consooomer fan bases around.

My point is that I think it's bad to generally characterize "not buying something" as what Pokémon nerds lie about, and that you can both complain to the developers of BF2 without also HAVING ALREADY GIVEN THEM YOUR MONEY.

Voting with your wallet is a solid strategy for people who aren't brainless children.

snippet.textDisplay:
Until you get over your desire to buy every game in a series, companies will never respect you. Until you actually withhold your financial support and stand on principle, it's all meaningless. Get another hobby and spend your money on that. That way, even if the games never get better, you won't care because you'll have other means of keeping yourself entertained. If your happiness is dependent on Pokemon or Modern Warfare, theres no incentive for Nintendo or Activision to listen to you. Let go of your codependency and you'll be a stronger person with broader horizons.

Jim, we welcome you to Pennsylvania, where every road is a winding path and every liquor store is a public works project.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is why I don't use the term boycott so damn frivolously. I don't boycott any specific publisher, so even though EA is shit, I'm not gonna say that I'll boycott all their games. Because if they publish a good game, I will want to play it. Boycotting a specific game is a bit different, but generally if you're gonna do it, then do it. Don't say you're gonna boycott and then go play the game anyway. If I have no intention of playing a game, then it's not getting played. That god awful remake of DMC is my constant example. As a fan of the proper Devil May Cry series, I didn't like what I saw and heard about the remake, so to this day I've never touched the game. My younger brother has it, he's played it, and doesn't have a problem with it. To quote "It's a remake, it's not part of the rest of the series' story. It's not that bad on it's own, and it's not a bad game, it's fine." While I do see the point of it's a remake it's not part of the series. That doesn't excuse it, these are established characters. Even if it's not the same story, the characters are special to people, it means something. Why the hell do you think people are pissed off about things like the live action adaptations of certain anime, like Death Note, Ghost in the Shell, or DragonBall Z. These things aren't completely disconnected, they have inherent meaning, to try and so drastically change that meaning (for the worse especially), is gonna cause a lot of people to be angry. And that's why despite my brother having the game, and me being able to play it, I won't touch it. Devil May Cry is a very important game series to me, I didn't entirely like the art and character style for 5, but that was entirely my own personal preferences. And the style it has isn't bad, it's actually good, I just prefer the way some of the previous games looked, namely 3 and 4. As such, there's no reason for me to not play 5, it's great, and it's a great addition to the series, that's proper Devil May Cry.


I've also considered playing Fallen Order due to how good it appears to be (I mean I technically have played it a bit, I played on my brother's account a bit), and that's published by EA. I will easily reward good games and behavior, that's what I think everyone should do. Reward games for doing a good job, not a crap job (looks at Anthem and Fallout 76, oh boy...), if you enjoy a game, even if it's bad, then that's fine. If something is objectively bad, but you still enjoy it, and want to support it, then that's your decision (though I'd argue against supporting a bad game, which is why I've not bought Fallout 76 or Anthem, played Anthem's beta, but didn't have money to buy it, so waited, saw a review and boy did I dodge a bullet, I initially gave benefit of the doubt to the beta because it was a beta, but the full release, no). So yeah, if you're gonna boycott something, boycott it, don't just say something and then do the opposite. That's what I expect from companies like EA, Activision, and others, don't be those guys, cause it's not good.

snippet.textDisplay: One thing I think we should consider is the demographics of these fanbases. One big difference is that a much greater proportion of the people who play Warcraft and Battlefront are adults. Pokemon's fanbase on the other hand, is mostly made up of children. So as passionate as me and my friends are about Pokemon, adult fans are still in the minority. Pokemon games are mostly played by kids who don't care, or perhaps aren't even aware of the particulars of the game, so long as it has lots of colorful critters and a Pikachu somewhere. Even if no adults ever buy Sword and Shield for themselves, that probably still adds up to like 15 million sales or something, just from the kiddies who begged their parents for it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the problem with boycotts is that action tends to be better than inaction.
A boycott is about getting people all to agree to NOT do a thing as part of a protest. Whereas the continual onslaught of complaining that happened with Battlefront II is an action.... and one that might result in fewer sales as you basically scare people away from it by showing how sh*t it is.


I don't think boycotting is bad. But when it comes to video games, where so much of the purchasing has come down to overly convenient online purchases where you likely never have to make eye contact with anyone and can convince yourself "well, it's okay if I buy this, that's just one person, no one will know".
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
If you don't like a game company and their practices, just stop buying their stuff. You can be as vocal as you like, tweet about it, whatever. Just stop actually buying the stuff they put out! It doesn't have to be an actual boycott or anything like that, just stop giving them your money if you don't like what they're doing! It probably won't make a big difference, but the more ppl that do it, the more impact it will have over time.


I don't buy EA or Ubisoft games anymore. I hate their stupid UPlay and Origin and I won't use them - I don't even look at their ads or what games they have coming out. They put out broken games regularly. I never preorder anymore and most of the games I buy are after I've watched Let's Plays or enough game footage from ppl online that I know what I'm getting into. I guess I don't buy Activision/Blizzard anymore either, but that was less of a conscious decision on my part and more along the lines of "they aren't making anything I'm interested in playing."


The more ppl that stop buying their shitty, overpriced/overmonetized products and switch to only buying games that don't do those things, the better off as a gaming community we will be. And if it's that difficult to pull yourself away from that kind of masochism, maybe stop watching videos about that stuff and the associated drama? Just don't pretend you're boycotting when you actually aren't.


Seriously, don't buy games you don't want! And if you do buy them anyway? Well, that's on you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Still think A Link to the Past is the best Zelda game. :p


As for the whole Boycott thing... yeah, gamers are dumb and never follow through. I know if I get upset with something a company is doing, or how a product is being handled, I won't buy it. If it's really bad, I won't even pirate it. :p


Personally, I'm done with Blizzard. I used to play Overwatch and Heroes of the Storm (without spending money), but after their last crap on their customers I just uninstalled all their stuff and decided to ignore the company from now on (well, unless somehow they break away from Activision and become a semi-decent company again). lol


It is frustrating to see "gamers" yelling about how they will refuse to buy a game, yet just go out and buy it anyway. Many still pre-order the games they say they're going to boycott. Lots of them make a big deal about waiting for the game to be on some big sale before they'll buy it, as if that's not still supporting the company. And in the end, it doesn't really matter. The percentage of people who actual care about what's going on in the gaming world, how companies act and all that, are a microscopic part of the target audience. For every person who refuses to buy a game (who would have bought it originally) there's going to be a good 10k+ who will buy it. Hell, a massive amount of sales don't even go to actual gamers anyway, it's parents who are blindly buying games for their kids because they're told to. Do you think the parents know about how shitty a company is? Or even care? No, they want to buy whatever will shut their spawn up for a while.
It's not like most parents even bother looking at the ESRB ratings on games before they buy them. Every time I hang out at the local EB to chat with friends, I see several parents always coming in to complain about how bad some game is (full of nudity and violence and such) and how dare the clerks sell the games to their kids... even though THEY were the ones who decided it was alright to buy them, not even bothering to look at the rating that would have told them exactly what was in the game.


Unless gamers can somehow unite several million people (who will actually stick to their promise to not buy a thing), there's no way any attempted boycott is ever going to do anything.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think this whole incident will damage Blizzard more than they realize. From what I have seen, they are not attracting a lot of new fans (or at the very least as many as they should for a storied company). With the near constant bad word of mouth and controversies surrounding Blizzard, its doing nothing but driving potential new fans away. The vast majority of fans it seems are older people who grew up with the company since the 90's and 2000's and have come to expect a high standard of quality. A standard Blizzard hasn't meet in many years.


I was on r/Blizzard this morning a read several posts from long time fans that they are finally giving up on Blizzard. From what I read it wasn't easy for these people because Blizzard's games are so entwined to their formative years. Like a long time friend that has slowly turned into a horrible person. You've built so many good memories together that it is hard to cut them out your life (I speak from experience).


As a causal observer (I've never played any of Blizzard's games) I do sympathize with the fans and to some degree get why they overlooked Blizzard's misdeeds for so long. However a belated wake-up call is a wake-up call nonetheless. You DO NOT owe any company your loyalty because you grew up with them. This isn't the 90's anymore; there are vastly more titles and developers out there that are more worth your time and money.


Cherish the memories you have, but let the past go and create new memories.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah, it's ultimately going to come down to people sticking to their personal values and discipline without succumbing to the desire for the short-term enjoyment before ACTUAL widespread change is felt.

I haven't bought anything from ActiBlizz, EA, 2K and Rockstar in a very long time (probably some others as well), refuse to install the Epic Store on anything I own, and will now be avoiding any of GameFreak's offerings, because frankly, anyone who has the fuckin' audacity to lie to my face while the evidence is laid out on the table, doesn't respect me and doesn't deserve mine in return. Fuck 'em. I am baffled by the amount of people just okay with it, though.
It does give me some satisfaction and peace of mind, but no actual happiness until the industry makes some positive changes and we can all just enjoy games again without someone trying to screw us over.
